AssociateMemberToFarm.name: AssociateMemberToFarm
AssociateMemberToFarm.documentation: Assigns a farm membership level to a member.

AssociateMemberToFleet.name: AssociateMemberToFleet
AssociateMemberToFleet.documentation: Assigns a fleet membership level to a member.

AssociateMemberToJob.name: AssociateMemberToJob
AssociateMemberToJob.documentation: Assigns a job membership level to a member

AssociateMemberToQueue.name: AssociateMemberToQueue
AssociateMemberToQueue.documentation: Assigns a queue membership level to a member

AssumeFleetRoleForRead.name: AssumeFleetRoleForRead
AssumeFleetRoleForRead.documentation: Get Amazon Web Services credentials from the fleet role. The IAM permissions of the credentials are scoped down to have read-only access.

AssumeFleetRoleForWorker.name: AssumeFleetRoleForWorker
AssumeFleetRoleForWorker.documentation: Get credentials from the fleet role for a worker.

AssumeQueueRoleForRead.name: AssumeQueueRoleForRead
AssumeQueueRoleForRead.documentation: Gets Amazon Web Services credentials from the queue role. The IAM permissions of the credentials are scoped down to have read-only access.

AssumeQueueRoleForUser.name: AssumeQueueRoleForUser
AssumeQueueRoleForUser.documentation: Allows a user to assume a role for a queue.

AssumeQueueRoleForWorker.name: AssumeQueueRoleForWorker
AssumeQueueRoleForWorker.documentation: Allows a worker to assume a queue role.

BatchGetJobEntity.name: BatchGetJobEntity
BatchGetJobEntity.documentation: Get batched job details for a worker.

CopyJobTemplate.name: CopyJobTemplate
CopyJobTemplate.documentation: Copies a job template to an Amazon S3 bucket.

CreateBudget.name: CreateBudget
CreateBudget.documentation: Creates a budget to set spending thresholds for your rendering activity.

CreateFarm.name: CreateFarm
CreateFarm.documentation: Creates a farm to allow space for queues and fleets. Farms are the space where the components of your renders gather and are pieced together in the cloud. Farms contain budgets and allow you to enforce permissions. Deadline Cloud farms are a useful container for large projects.

CreateFleet.name: CreateFleet
CreateFleet.documentation: Creates a fleet. Fleets gather information relating to compute, or capacity, for renders within your farms. You can choose to manage your own capacity or opt to have fleets fully managed by Deadline Cloud.

CreateJob.name: CreateJob
CreateJob.documentation: Creates a job. A job is a set of instructions that Deadline Cloud uses to schedule and run work on available workers. For more information, see Deadline Cloud jobs.

CreateLicenseEndpoint.name: CreateLicenseEndpoint
CreateLicenseEndpoint.documentation: Creates a license endpoint to integrate your various licensed software used for rendering on Deadline Cloud.

CreateLimit.name: CreateLimit
CreateLimit.documentation:
Creates a limit that manages the distribution of shared resources, such as floating licenses. A limit can throttle work assignments, help manage workloads, and track current usage. Before you use a limit, you must associate the limit with one or more queues.

You must add the amountRequirementName to a step in a job template to declare the limit requirement.

CreateMonitor.name: CreateMonitor
CreateMonitor.documentation: Creates an Amazon Web Services Deadline Cloud monitor that you can use to view your farms, queues, and fleets. After you submit a job, you can track the progress of the tasks and steps that make up the job, and then download the job's results.

CreateQueue.name: CreateQueue
CreateQueue.documentation: Creates a queue to coordinate the order in which jobs run on a farm. A queue can also specify where to pull resources and indicate where to output completed jobs.

CreateQueueEnvironment.name: CreateQueueEnvironment
CreateQueueEnvironment.documentation: Creates an environment for a queue that defines how jobs in the queue run.

CreateQueueFleetAssociation.name: CreateQueueFleetAssociation
CreateQueueFleetAssociation.documentation: Creates an association between a queue and a fleet.

CreateQueueLimitAssociation.name: CreateQueueLimitAssociation
CreateQueueLimitAssociation.documentation: Associates a limit with a particular queue. After the limit is associated, all workers for jobs that specify the limit associated with the queue are subject to the limit. You can't associate two limits with the same amountRequirementName to the same queue.

CreateStorageProfile.name: CreateStorageProfile
CreateStorageProfile.documentation: Creates a storage profile that specifies the operating system, file type, and file location of resources used on a farm.

CreateWorker.name: CreateWorker
CreateWorker.documentation:
Creates a worker. A worker tells your instance how much processing power (vCPU), and memory (GiB) youâ€™ll need to assemble the digital assets held within a particular instance. You can specify certain instance types to use, or let the worker know which instances types to exclude.

Deadline Cloud limits the number of workers to less than or equal to the fleet's maximum worker count. The service maintains eventual consistency for the worker count. If you make multiple rapid calls to CreateWorker before the field updates, you might exceed your fleet's maximum worker count. For example, if your maxWorkerCount is 10 and you currently have 9 workers, making two quick CreateWorker calls might successfully create 2 workers instead of 1, resulting in 11 total workers.

DeleteLimit.name: DeleteLimit
DeleteLimit.documentation: Removes a limit from the specified farm. Before you delete a limit you must use the DeleteQueueLimitAssociation operation to remove the association with any queues.

DeleteMonitor.name: DeleteMonitor
DeleteMonitor.documentation: Removes a Deadline Cloud monitor. After you delete a monitor, you can create a new one and attach farms to the monitor.

DeleteQueue.name: DeleteQueue
DeleteQueue.documentation:
Deletes a queue.

You can't recover the jobs in a queue if you delete the queue. Deleting the queue also deletes the jobs in that queue.

DeleteQueueLimitAssociation.name: DeleteQueueLimitAssociation
DeleteQueueLimitAssociation.documentation: Removes the association between a queue and a limit. You must use the UpdateQueueLimitAssociation operation to set the status to STOP_LIMIT_USAGE_AND_COMPLETE_TASKS or STOP_LIMIT_USAGE_AND_CANCEL_TASKS. The status does not change immediately. Use the GetQueueLimitAssociation operation to see if the status changed to STOPPED before deleting the association.

GetQueueLimitAssociation.name: GetQueueLimitAssociation
GetQueueLimitAssociation.documentation: Gets information about a specific association between a queue and a limit.

GetSessionAction.name: GetSessionAction
GetSessionAction.documentation: Gets a session action for the job.

GetSessionsStatisticsAggregation.name: GetSessionsStatisticsAggregation
GetSessionsStatisticsAggregation.documentation: Gets a set of statistics for queues or farms. Before you can call the GetSessionStatisticsAggregation operation, you must first call the StartSessionsStatisticsAggregation operation. Statistics are available for 1 hour after you call the StartSessionsStatisticsAggregation operation.

GetStorageProfileForQueue.name: GetStorageProfileForQueue
GetStorageProfileForQueue.documentation: Gets a storage profile for a queue.

ListAvailableMeteredProducts.name: ListAvailableMeteredProducts
ListAvailableMeteredProducts.documentation: A list of the available metered products.

ListBudgets.name: ListBudgets
ListBudgets.documentation: A list of budgets in a farm.

ListLimits.name: ListLimits
ListLimits.documentation: Gets a list of limits defined in the specified farm.

ListMonitors.name: ListMonitors
ListMonitors.documentation: Gets a list of your monitors in Deadline Cloud.

ListQueueLimitAssociations.name: ListQueueLimitAssociations
ListQueueLimitAssociations.documentation: Gets a list of the associations between queues and limits defined in a farm.

StartSessionsStatisticsAggregation.name: StartSessionsStatisticsAggregation
StartSessionsStatisticsAggregation.documentation: Starts an asynchronous request for getting aggregated statistics about queues and farms. Get the statistics using the GetSessionsStatisticsAggregation operation. You can only have one running aggregation for your Deadline Cloud farm. Call the GetSessionsStatisticsAggregation operation and check the status field to see if an aggregation is running. Statistics are available for 1 hour after you call the StartSessionsStatisticsAggregation operation.

TagResource.name: TagResource
TagResource.documentation: Tags a resource using the resource's ARN and desired tags.

UntagResource.name: UntagResource
UntagResource.documentation: Removes a tag from a resource using the resource's ARN and tag to remove.

UpdateBudget.name: UpdateBudget
UpdateBudget.documentation: Updates a budget that sets spending thresholds for rendering activity.

UpdateJob.name: UpdateJob
UpdateJob.documentation:
Updates a job.

When you change the status of the job to ARCHIVED, the job can't be scheduled or archived.

An archived jobs and its steps and tasks are deleted after 120 days. The job can't be recovered.

UpdateLimit.name: UpdateLimit
UpdateLimit.documentation: Updates the properties of the specified limit.

UpdateMonitor.name: UpdateMonitor
UpdateMonitor.documentation: Modifies the settings for a Deadline Cloud monitor. You can modify one or all of the settings when you call UpdateMonitor.

UpdateQueueLimitAssociation.name: UpdateQueueLimitAssociation
UpdateQueueLimitAssociation.documentation: Updates the status of the queue. If you set the status to one of the STOP_LIMIT_USAGE* values, there will be a delay before the status transitions to the STOPPED state.

selections.documentation: A list of accelerator capabilities requested for this fleet. Only Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud instances that provide these capabilities will be used. For example, if you specify both L4 and T4 chips, Deadline Cloud will use Amazon EC2 instances that have either the L4 or the T4 chip installed.

count.documentation: The number of GPU accelerators specified for worker hosts in this fleet.

AcceleratorCapabilities.documentation: Provides information about the GPU accelerators used for jobs processed by a fleet.

min.documentation: The minimum number of GPU accelerators in the worker host.

max.documentation: The maximum number of GPU accelerators in the worker host.

AcceleratorCountRange.documentation: Defines the maximum and minimum number of GPU accelerators required for a worker instance..

name.documentation:
The name of the chip used by the GPU accelerator.

If you specify l4 as the name of the accelerator, you must specify latest or grid:r570 as the runtime.

The available GPU accelerators are:

  • t4 - NVIDIA T4 Tensor Core GPU

  • a10g - NVIDIA A10G Tensor Core GPU

  • l4 - NVIDIA L4 Tensor Core GPU

  • l40s - NVIDIA L40S Tensor Core GPU

runtime.documentation:
Specifies the runtime driver to use for the GPU accelerator. You must use the same runtime for all GPUs.

You can choose from the following runtimes:

  • latest - Use the latest runtime available for the chip. If you specify latest and a new version of the runtime is released, the new version of the runtime is used.

  • grid:r570 - NVIDIA vGPU software 18

  • grid:r535 - NVIDIA vGPU software 16

If you don't specify a runtime, Deadline Cloud uses latest as the default. However, if you have multiple accelerators and specify latest for some and leave others blank, Deadline Cloud raises an exception.

AcceleratorSelection.documentation: Describes a specific GPU accelerator required for an Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud worker host.

min.documentation: The minimum amount of memory to use for the accelerator, measured in MiB.

max.documentation: The maximum amount of memory to use for the accelerator, measured in MiB.

AcceleratorTotalMemoryMiBRange.documentation: Defines the maximum and minimum amount of memory, in MiB, to use for the accelerator.

  • ACTIVEâ€“The budget is being evaluated.

  • INACTIVEâ€“The budget is inactive. This can include Expired, Canceled, or deleted Deleted statuses.

This field can store any content. Escape or encode this content before displaying it on a webpage or any other system that might interpret the content of this field.

The display name of the fleet.

This field can store any content. Escape or encode this content before displaying it on a webpage or any other system that might interpret the content of this field.

This field can store any content. Escape or encode this content before displaying it on a webpage or any other system that might interpret the content of this field.

roleArn.documentation: The IAM role ARN for the role that the fleet's workers will use.

maxWorkerCount.documentation:
The maximum number of workers for the fleet.

Deadline Cloud limits the number of workers to less than or equal to the fleet's maximum worker count. The service maintains eventual consistency for the worker count. If you make multiple rapid calls to CreateWorker before the field updates, you might exceed your fleet's maximum worker count. For example, if your maxWorkerCount is 10 and you currently have 9 workers, making two quick CreateWorker calls might successfully create 2 workers instead of 1, resulting in 11 total workers.

configuration.documentation: The configuration settings for the fleet. Customer managed fleets are self-managed. Service managed Amazon EC2 fleets are managed by Deadline Cloud.

tags.documentation: Each tag consists of a tag key and a tag value. Tag keys and values are both required, but tag values can be empty strings.

hostConfiguration.documentation: Provides a script that runs as a worker is starting up that you can use to provide additional configuration for workers in your fleet.

templateType.documentation: The file type for the job template.

priority.documentation: The priority of the job. The highest priority (first scheduled) is 100. When two jobs have the same priority, the oldest job is scheduled first.

attachments.documentation: The attachments for the job. Attach files required for the job to run to a render job.

storageProfileId.documentation: The storage profile ID for the storage profile to connect to the job.

targetTaskRunStatus.documentation: The initial job status when it is created. Jobs that are created with a SUSPENDED status will not run until manually requeued.

maxFailedTasksCount.documentation: The number of task failures before the job stops running and is marked as FAILED.

maxRetriesPerTask.documentation: The maximum number of retries for each task.

maxWorkerCount.documentation:
The maximum number of worker hosts that can concurrently process a job. When the maxWorkerCount is reached, no more workers will be assigned to process the job, even if the fleets assigned to the job's queue has available workers.

You can't set the maxWorkerCount to 0. If you set it to -1, there is no maximum number of workers.

If you don't specify the maxWorkerCount, Deadline Cloud won't throttle the number of workers used to process the job.

sourceJobId.documentation: The job ID for the source job.

clientToken.documentation: The unique token which the server uses to recognize retries of the same request.

This field can store any content. Escape or encode this content before displaying it on a webpage or any other system that might interpret the content of this field.

maxCount.documentation:
The maximum number of resources constrained by this limit. When all of the resources are in use, steps that require the limit won't be scheduled until the resource is available.

The maxCount must not be 0. If the value is -1, there is no restriction on the number of resources that can be acquired for this limit.

tagPropagationMode.documentation:
Specifies whether tags associated with a fleet are attached to workers when the worker is launched.

When the tagPropagationMode is set to PROPAGATE_TAGS_TO_WORKERS_AT_LAUNCH any tag associated with a fleet is attached to workers when they launch. If the tags for a fleet change, the tags associated with running workers do not change.

If you don't specify tagPropagationMode, the default is NO_PROPAGATION.

To retrieve the next page, call the operation again using the returned token. Keep all other arguments unchanged. If no results remain, then nextToken is set to null. If you call the StartSessionsStatisticsAggregation operation when the status is IN_PROGRESS, you will receive a ThrottlingException.

scriptBody.documentation:
The text of the script that runs as a worker is starting up that you can use to provide additional configuration for workers in your fleet. The script runs after a worker enters the STARTING state and before the worker processes tasks.

For more information about using the script, see Run scripts as an administrator to configure workers in the Deadline Cloud Developer Guide.

The script runs as an administrative user (sudo root on Linux, as an Administrator on Windows).

scriptTimeoutSeconds.documentation:
The maximum time that the host configuration can run. If the timeout expires, the worker enters the NOT RESPONDING state and shuts down. You are charged for the time that the worker is running the host configuration script.

You should configure your fleet for a maximum of one worker while testing your host configuration script to avoid starting additional workers.

The default is 300 seconds (5 minutes).

HostConfiguration.documentation:
Provides a script that runs as a worker is starting up that you can use to provide additional configuration for workers in your fleet.

To remove a script from a fleet, use the UpdateFleet operation with the hostConfiguration scriptBody parameter set to an empty string ("").

taskRunStatus.documentation:
The task run status for the job.

  • PENDINGâ€“pending and waiting for resources.

  • READYâ€“ready to be processed.

  • ASSIGNEDâ€“assigned and will run next on a worker.

  • SCHEDULEDâ€“scheduled to be run on a worker.

  • INTERRUPTINGâ€“being interrupted.

  • RUNNINGâ€“running on a worker.

  • SUSPENDEDâ€“the task is suspended.

  • CANCELEDâ€“the task has been canceled.

  • FAILEDâ€“the task has failed.

  • SUCCEEDEDâ€“the task has succeeded.

The maximum number of worker hosts that can concurrently process a job. When the maxWorkerCount is reached, no more workers will be assigned to process the job, even if the fleets assigned to the job's queue has available workers.

If you don't specify the maxWorkerCount, the default is -1.

The task run status for the job.

  • PENDINGâ€“pending and waiting for resources.

  • READYâ€“ready to be processed.

  • ASSIGNEDâ€“assigned and will run next on a worker.

  • SCHEDULEDâ€“scheduled to be run on a worker.

  • INTERRUPTINGâ€“being interrupted.

  • RUNNINGâ€“running on a worker.

  • SUSPENDEDâ€“the task is suspended.

  • CANCELEDâ€“the task has been canceled.

  • FAILEDâ€“the task has failed.

  • SUCCEEDEDâ€“the task has succeeded.

minWorkerCount.documentation: The minimum number of workers in the fleet.

maxWorkerCount.documentation:
The maximum number of workers in the fleet.

Deadline Cloud limits the number of workers to less than or equal to the fleet's maximum worker count. The service maintains eventual consistency for the worker count. If you make multiple rapid calls to CreateWorker before the field updates, you might exceed your fleet's maximum worker count. For example, if your maxWorkerCount is 10 and you currently have 9 workers, making two quick CreateWorker calls might successfully create 2 workers instead of 1, resulting in 11 total workers.

lifecycleStatus.documentation:
The status of a job in its lifecycle. When you change the status of the job to ARCHIVED, the job can't be scheduled or archived.

An archived jobs and its steps and tasks are deleted after 120 days. The job can't be recovered.

maxWorkerCount.documentation:
The maximum number of worker hosts that can concurrently process a job. When the maxWorkerCount is reached, no more workers will be assigned to process the job, even if the fleets assigned to the job's queue has available workers.

You can't set the maxWorkerCount to 0. If you set it to -1, there is no maximum number of workers.

If you don't specify the maxWorkerCount, the default is -1.

The maximum number of workers that can process tasks in the job.

maxCount.documentation:
The maximum number of resources constrained by this limit. When all of the resources are in use, steps that require the limit won't be scheduled until the resource is available.

If more than the new maximum number is currently in use, running jobs finish but no new jobs are started until the number of resources in use is below the new maximum number.

The maxCount must not be 0. If the value is -1, there is no restriction on the number of resources that can be acquired for this limit.

documentation:
The Amazon Web Services Deadline Cloud API provides infrastructure and centralized management for your projects. Use the Deadline Cloud API to onboard users, assign projects, and attach permissions specific to their job function.

With Deadline Cloud, content production teams can deploy resources for their workforce securely in the cloud, reducing the costs of added physical infrastructure. Keep your content production operations secure, while allowing your contributors to access the tools they need, such as scalable high-speed storage, licenses, and cost management services.
